title: 3D Gaussian Splatting aided Localization for Large and Complex Indoor Environments
author: Vincent Ress (University of Stuttgart), Jonas Meyer (University of Stuttgart), Wei Zhang (University of Stuttgart), David Skuddis (University of Stuttgart), Uwe Soergel (University of Stuttgart), Norbert Haala (University of Stuttgart), ..., Norbert Haala.
relevance_why: The paper discusses advancements in localization methods that can potentially be applied to improve audio-visual systems where spatial awareness is crucial, such as in audio scene understanding.
background: The paper addresses visual localization in large, complex indoor environments, enhancing pose estimation through the integration of 3D Gaussian Splatting.
contribution: This study introduces 3D Gaussian Splatting as a novel representation technique to improve localization accuracy in challenging indoor environments, achieving significant improvements in visual localization methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often struggled with perspective differences and low texture areas, leading to reduced accuracy under various conditions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work overcomes these limitations by generating additional rendered views from 3D Gaussian representations, enhancing dataset quality and coverage.

key_innovation: Combining a photorealistic representation with dense visual mapping to improve the robustness of visual localization algorithms in complex settings.
real_world_impact: The findings can lead to enhanced robotic navigation systems within indoor environments, relevant for construction automation and autonomous systems. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The inclusion of rendered images doubles the training time, which may raise concerns for real-time applications.

new_terms.3D Gaussian Splatting: **3D Gaussian Splatting** is a technique that uses Gaussian functions to represent 3D objects, enabling efficient rendering and manipulation of visual data for better scene understanding.
